title: Mozambique votes in test of fragile peace deal
text:
Mozambique’s president was on course for re-election today after a controversial campaign marred by the murder of a senior election observer reawakened fears of a return to violence in a country plagued by a history of civil war.

President Filipe Nyusi of the Frelimo party has headed a particularly fraught campaign dogged by claims of killings, intimidation and electoral fraud. Although he is widely expected to win, an election seen as less than credible could undermine a two-month-old peace deal ending hostilities with Frelimo’s old foe, the Renamo party.

The stakes this time round are particularly high. Impoverished Mozambique is on the threshold of becoming a major gas exporter, and a return to violence would spook investors and donors that have helped it recover from a corruption-induced debt scandal and Cyclone Idai, which ravaged swathes of the country earlier this year.

“Mozambique has chosen peace,” Mr Nyusi said after casting his ballot in the capital, Maputo.

Voting passed off without major incident, although seven polling stations in the north, where an Islamist insurgency has killed hundreds, were closed, denying some the chance to vote.

But pre-election skulduggery has exacerbated tensions. Earlier this month, Anastasio Matavel, a senior election observer, was killed in the pro-government Gaza province, with police forced to acknowledge responsibility.
description: Mozambique’s president was on course for re-election today after a controversial campaign marred by the murder of a senior election observer reawakened fears of a return to violence in a country plagued by a history of civil war.
